Trilinear Forms with Double Kloosterman Sums

Igor E. Shparlinski Department of Pure Mathematics, University of New South Wales, Sydney, NSW 2052, Australia igor.shparlinski@unsw.edu.au
Abstract.

We obtain several estimates for trilinear form with double Kloosterman sums. In particular, these bounds show the existence of nontrivial cancellations between such sums.

Key words and phrases:
Double Kloosterman sum, cancellation, trilinear form
2010 Mathematics Subject Classification:
11D79, 11L07
This work was supported by ARC Grant DP170100786.

1. Introduction

1.1. Background and motivation

Let q𝑞q be a positive integer. We denote the residue ring modulo q𝑞q by ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞{\mathbb{Z}}_{q} and denote the group of units of ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞{\mathbb{Z}}_{q} by ℤq∗superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞{\mathbb{Z}}_{q}^{*}.

For integers ℓℓ\ell, m𝑚m and n𝑛n we define the double Kloosterman sum

𝒦q​(ℓ,m,n)=∑x,y∈ℤq∗𝐞q​(ℓ​x​y+m​x¯+n​y¯).subscript𝒦𝑞ℓ𝑚𝑛subscript𝑥𝑦superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞subscript𝐞𝑞ℓ𝑥𝑦𝑚¯𝑥𝑛¯𝑦{\mathcal{K}}_{q}(\ell,m,n)=\sum_{x,y\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{q}^{*}}{\mathbf{\,e}}_{q}\left(\ell xy+m\overline{x}+n\overline{y}\right).

where x¯¯𝑥\overline{x} is the multiplicative inverse of x𝑥x modulo q𝑞q and

𝐞q​(z)=exp⁡(2​π​i​z/q).subscript𝐞𝑞𝑧2𝜋𝑖𝑧𝑞{\mathbf{\,e}}_{q}(z)=\exp(2\pi iz/q).

Given three sets

ℒℒ\displaystyle{\mathcal{L}} ={u+1,…,u+L},absent𝑢1…𝑢𝐿\displaystyle=\{u+1,\ldots,u+L\},
ℳℳ\displaystyle{\mathcal{M}} ={v+1,…,v+M},absent𝑣1…𝑣𝑀\displaystyle=\{v+1,\ldots,v+M\},
𝒩𝒩\displaystyle{\mathcal{N}} ={w+1,…,w+N},absent𝑤1…𝑤𝑁\displaystyle=\{w+1,\ldots,w+N\},

of L𝐿L, M𝑀M, N𝑁N consecutive integers and a sequence of weights 𝜶={αℓ}ℓ∈ℒ𝜶subscriptsubscript𝛼ℓℓℒ\bm{\alpha}=\{\alpha_{\ell}\}_{\ell\in{\mathcal{L}}}, we define the weighted triple sums of double Kloosterman sums

𝒮q​(𝜶;ℒ,ℳ,𝒩)=∑ℓ∈ℒαℓ​∑m∈ℳ∑n∈𝒩𝒦q​(ℓ,m,n).subscript𝒮𝑞𝜶ℒℳ𝒩subscriptℓℒsubscript𝛼ℓsubscript𝑚ℳsubscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝒦𝑞ℓ𝑚𝑛{\mathcal{S}}_{q}(\bm{\alpha};{\mathcal{L}},{\mathcal{M}},{\mathcal{N}})=\sum_{\ell\in{\mathcal{L}}}\alpha_{\ell}\sum_{m\in{\mathcal{M}}}\sum_{n\in{\mathcal{N}}}{\mathcal{K}}_{q}(\ell,m,n).

Assuming that αℓ=0subscript𝛼ℓ0\alpha_{\ell}=0 if gcd⁡(ℓ,q)>1ℓ𝑞1\gcd(\ell,q)>1 and using the Weil bound [9, Equation (11.58)], one can easily obtain

|𝒮q​(𝜶;ℒ,ℳ,𝒩)|≤M​N​q1+o​(1)​∑ℓ∈ℒ|αℓ|,subscript𝒮𝑞𝜶ℒℳ𝒩𝑀𝑁superscript𝑞1𝑜1subscriptℓℒsubscript𝛼ℓ\left|{\mathcal{S}}_{q}(\bm{\alpha};{\mathcal{L}},{\mathcal{M}},{\mathcal{N}})\right|\leq MNq^{1+o(1)}\sum_{\ell\in{\mathcal{L}}}|\alpha_{\ell}|,

which in the case |αℓ|≤1subscript𝛼ℓ1|\alpha_{\ell}|\leq 1 takes form

(1.1) |𝒮q​(𝜶;ℒ,ℳ,𝒩)|≤L​M​N​q1+o​(1).subscript𝒮𝑞𝜶ℒℳ𝒩𝐿𝑀𝑁superscript𝑞1𝑜1\left|{\mathcal{S}}_{q}(\bm{\alpha};{\mathcal{L}},{\mathcal{M}},{\mathcal{N}})\right|\leq LMNq^{1+o(1)}.

We are interested in studying cancellations amongst Kloosterman sums and thus in improvements of the trivial bound (1.1).

This question is partially motivated by a series of recent results concerning various bilinear forms with single Kloosterman sums

𝒦q​(m,n)=∑x,y∈ℤq∗𝐞q​(m​x+n​x¯),subscript𝒦𝑞𝑚𝑛subscript𝑥𝑦superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞subscript𝐞𝑞𝑚𝑥𝑛¯𝑥{\mathcal{K}}_{q}(m,n)=\sum_{x,y\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{q}^{*}}{\mathbf{\,e}}_{q}\left(mx+n\overline{x}\right),

see [1, 2, 5, 11, 12, 13] and references therein for various approaches, and also for generalisation to bilinear forms with more general quantities. The triple sums 𝒮q​(𝜶;ℒ,ℳ,𝒩)subscript𝒮𝑞𝜶ℒℳ𝒩{\mathcal{S}}_{q}(\bm{\alpha};{\mathcal{L}},{\mathcal{M}},{\mathcal{N}}) seems to be a new object of study.

1.2. Results

Here we use some ideas from [12, 13] to improve the trivial bound (1.1). Although the approach works in larger generality, to exhibit it in a simplest form we assume that weights 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha} supported only on ℓ∈ℤq∗ℓsuperscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞\ell\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{q}^{*}, that is, that αℓ=0subscript𝛼ℓ0\alpha_{\ell}=0 if gcd⁡(ℓ,q)=1ℓ𝑞1\gcd(\ell,q)=1.

Theorem 1.1.

For any integer q≥1𝑞1q\geq 1, and weights 𝛂={αℓ}ℓ∈ℒ𝛂subscriptsubscript𝛼ℓℓℒ\bm{\alpha}=\{\alpha_{\ell}\}_{\ell\in{\mathcal{L}}} with |αℓ|≤1subscript𝛼ℓ1|\alpha_{\ell}|\leq 1 and supported only on ℓ∈ℤq∗ℓsuperscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞\ell\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{q}^{*}, we have,

|𝒮q​(𝜶;ℒ,ℳ,𝒩)|subscript𝒮𝑞𝜶ℒℳ𝒩\displaystyle|{\mathcal{S}}_{q}(\bm{\alpha};{\mathcal{L}},{\mathcal{M}},{\mathcal{N}})|
≤min{(L+L1/2M1/2)N1/2q3/2,\displaystyle\qquad\leq\min\bigl{\{}\left(L+L^{1/2}M^{1/2}\right)N^{1/2}q^{3/2},
(L+L3/4M1/4)(N1/8q7/4+N1/2q3/2)}qo​(1).\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\left(L+L^{3/4}M^{1/4}\right)\left(N^{1/8}q^{7/4}+N^{1/2}q^{3/2}\right)\bigr{\}}q^{o(1)}.
Theorem 1.2.

For any fixed real ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 and integer r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2, for any sufficiently large Q≥1𝑄1Q\geq 1, for all but at most Q1−2​r​ε+o​(1)superscript𝑄12𝑟𝜀𝑜1Q^{1-2r\varepsilon+o(1)} integers q∈[Q,2​Q]𝑞𝑄2𝑄q\in[Q,2Q] and weights 𝛂q={αq,ℓ}ℓ∈ℒsubscript𝛂𝑞subscriptsubscript𝛼𝑞ℓℓℒ\bm{\alpha}_{q}=\{\alpha_{q,\ell}\}_{\ell\in{\mathcal{L}}}, that may depend on q𝑞q, with |αq,ℓ|≤1subscript𝛼𝑞ℓ1|\alpha_{q,\ell}|\leq 1 and supported only on ℓ∈ℤq∗ℓsuperscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞\ell\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{q}^{*}, we have,

|𝒮q​(𝜶q;ℒ,ℳ,𝒩)|≤(L+L1−1/2​r​M1/2​r)​(q2−1/2​r+N1/2​q3/2)​qo​(1).subscript𝒮𝑞subscript𝜶𝑞ℒℳ𝒩𝐿superscript𝐿112𝑟superscript𝑀12𝑟superscript𝑞212𝑟superscript𝑁12superscript𝑞32superscript𝑞𝑜1|{\mathcal{S}}_{q}(\bm{\alpha}_{q};{\mathcal{L}},{\mathcal{M}},{\mathcal{N}})|\leq\left(L+L^{1-1/2r}M^{1/2r}\right)\left(q^{2-1/2r}+N^{1/2}q^{3/2}\right)q^{o(1)}.

Clearly, the roles of M𝑀M and N𝑁N can be interchanged in Theorems 1.1 and 1.2.

Now, assuming that N≤q2/3+o​(1)𝑁superscript𝑞23𝑜1N\leq q^{2/3+o(1)} we have N1/8​q7/4≥N1/2​q3/2+o​(1)superscript𝑁18superscript𝑞74superscript𝑁12superscript𝑞32𝑜1N^{1/8}q^{7/4}\geq N^{1/2}q^{3/2+o(1)}. Hence by Theorems 1.1 we have

|𝒮q​(𝜶;ℒ,ℳ,𝒩)|≤(L+L3/4​M1/4)​N1/8​q7/4+o​(1),subscript𝒮𝑞𝜶ℒℳ𝒩𝐿superscript𝐿34superscript𝑀14superscript𝑁18superscript𝑞74𝑜1|{\mathcal{S}}_{q}(\bm{\alpha};{\mathcal{L}},{\mathcal{M}},{\mathcal{N}})|\leq\left(L+L^{3/4}M^{1/4}\right)N^{1/8}q^{7/4+o(1)},

which improves (1.1) for

N≤q2/3+o​(1)andmin⁡{L,M}​M3​N7/2≥q3+εformulae-sequence𝑁superscript𝑞23𝑜1and𝐿𝑀superscript𝑀3superscript𝑁72superscript𝑞3𝜀N\leq q^{2/3+o(1)}\qquad\mbox{and}\qquad\min\{L,M\}M^{3}N^{7/2}\geq q^{3+\varepsilon}

for some fixed ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0. Thus in the symmetric case when L∼M∼Nsimilar-to𝐿𝑀similar-to𝑁L\sim M\sim N this condition becomes q2/3+o​(1)≥L≥q2/5+εsuperscript𝑞23𝑜1𝐿superscript𝑞25𝜀q^{2/3+o(1)}\geq L\geq q^{2/5+\varepsilon}.

1.3. Possible generalisations and open problems

Analysing the proofs of Theorems 1.1 and 1.2 one can easily see that they can be extended to more general sums of the form

∑x,y∈ℤq∗ηx​κy​𝐞q​(ℓ​x​y+m​x¯+n​y¯),subscript𝑥𝑦superscriptsubscriptℤ𝑞subscript𝜂𝑥subscript𝜅𝑦subscript𝐞𝑞ℓ𝑥𝑦𝑚¯𝑥𝑛¯𝑦\sum_{x,y\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{q}^{*}}\eta_{x}\kappa_{y}{\mathbf{\,e}}_{q}\left(\ell xy+m\overline{x}+n\overline{y}\right),

with complex weights satisfying |ηx|,|κy|≤1subscript𝜂𝑥subscript𝜅𝑦1|\eta_{x}|,|\kappa_{y}|\leq 1 (which may depend on q𝑞q in the settings of Theorem 1.2).

On the other hand, our approach does not work for the sums

∑ℓ∈ℒαℓ​∑m∈ℳβm​∑n∈𝒩𝒦q​(ℓ,m,n)and∑ℓ∈ℒαℓ​∑m∈ℳβm​∑n∈𝒩γn​𝒦q​(ℓ,m,n)subscriptℓℒsubscript𝛼ℓsubscript𝑚ℳsubscript𝛽𝑚subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝒦𝑞ℓ𝑚𝑛andsubscriptℓℒsubscript𝛼ℓsubscript𝑚ℳsubscript𝛽𝑚subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝛾𝑛subscript𝒦𝑞ℓ𝑚𝑛\sum_{\ell\in{\mathcal{L}}}\alpha_{\ell}\sum_{m\in{\mathcal{M}}}\beta_{m}\sum_{n\in{\mathcal{N}}}{\mathcal{K}}_{q}(\ell,m,n)\quad\text{and}\quad\sum_{\ell\in{\mathcal{L}}}\alpha_{\ell}\sum_{m\in{\mathcal{M}}}\beta_{m}\sum_{n\in{\mathcal{N}}}\gamma_{n}{\mathcal{K}}_{q}(\ell,m,n)

with nontrivial weights attached to the variables m𝑚m and n𝑛n. It is however possible that one can apply to these sums the method of [1, 5, 11].

2. Preliminaries

2.1. General notation

We always assume that the sequence of weights 𝜶={αℓ}ℓ∈ℒ𝜶subscriptsubscript𝛼ℓℓℒ\bm{\alpha}=\{\alpha_{\ell}\}_{\ell\in{\mathcal{L}}} is supported only on ℓℓ\ell with gcd⁡(ℓ,q)=1ℓ𝑞1\gcd(\ell,q)=1, that is, we have αℓ=0subscript𝛼ℓ0\alpha_{\ell}=0 if gcd⁡(ℓ,q)>1ℓ𝑞1\gcd(\ell,q)>1 (and the same for the weights 𝜶q={αq,ℓ}ℓ∈ℒsubscript𝜶𝑞subscriptsubscript𝛼𝑞ℓℓℒ\bm{\alpha}_{q}=\{\alpha_{q,\ell}\}_{\ell\in{\mathcal{L}}} depending on q𝑞q).

Throughout the paper, as usual A≪Bmuch-less-than𝐴𝐵A\ll B and B≫Amuch-greater-than𝐵𝐴B\gg A are equivalent to the inequality |A|≤c​B𝐴𝑐𝐵|A|\leq cB with some constant c>0𝑐0c>0, which occasionally, where obvious, may depend on the real parameter ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 and on the integer parameter r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1, and is absolute otherwise.

2.2. Number of solutions to some multiplicative congruences

We start with some estimates on power moments of character sums. Let 𝒳qsubscript𝒳𝑞{\mathcal{X}}_{q} be the set of all multiplicative characters χ𝜒\chi modulo q𝑞q and let 𝒳q∗=𝒳q∖{χ0}superscriptsubscript𝒳𝑞subscript𝒳𝑞subscript𝜒0{\mathcal{X}}_{q}^{*}={\mathcal{X}}_{q}\setminus\{\chi_{0}\} be the set of non-principal characters.

The first result is a special case of a bound of Cochrane and Shi [4, Theorem 1].

Lemma 2.1.

For any integers k𝑘k and H𝐻H we have

∑χ∈𝒳q|∑z=k+1k+Hχ​(x)|4≤H2​qo​(1).subscript𝜒subscript𝒳𝑞superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑧𝑘1𝑘𝐻𝜒𝑥4superscript𝐻2superscript𝑞𝑜1\sum_{\chi\in{\mathcal{X}}_{q}}\left|\sum_{z=k+1}^{k+H}\chi(x)\right|^{4}\leq H^{2}q^{o(1)}.

We now derive our main technical tool.

Lemma 2.2.

For any sets

𝒜={s+1,…,s+A}andℬ={t+1,…,t+B}formulae-sequence𝒜𝑠1…𝑠𝐴andℬ𝑡1…𝑡𝐵{\mathcal{A}}=\{s+1,\ldots,s+A\}\qquad\mbox{and}\qquad{\mathcal{B}}=\{t+1,\ldots,t+B\}

consisting of A𝐴A and B𝐵B consecutive integers, respectively, for

E(𝒜,ℬ)={a1b1≡a2b2modq:a1,a2∈𝒜,\displaystyle E({\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}})=\{a_{1}b_{1}\equiv a_{2}b_{2}\bmod q~{}:~{}a_{1},a_{2}\in{\mathcal{A}}, b1,b2∈ℬ,subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2ℬ\displaystyle\ b_{1},b_{2}\in{\mathcal{B}},
gcd(a1a2b1b2,q)=1}\displaystyle\gcd(a_{1}a_{2}b_{1}b_{2},q)=1\}

we have

E​(𝒜,ℬ)≤(A2​B2q+A​B)​qo​(1).𝐸𝒜ℬsuperscript𝐴2superscript𝐵2𝑞𝐴𝐵superscript𝑞𝑜1E({\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}})\leq\left(\frac{A^{2}B^{2}}{q}+AB\right)q^{o(1)}.
Proof.

Using the orthogonality of characters, we write

E​(𝒜,ℬ)=∑a1,a2∈𝒜gcd⁡(a1​a2,q)=1∑b1,b2∈𝒜gcd⁡(b1​b2,q)=11φ​(q)​∑χ∈𝒳qχ​(a1​a2​b1−1​b2−1),𝐸𝒜ℬsubscriptsubscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2𝒜subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2𝑞1subscriptsubscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2𝒜subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2𝑞11𝜑𝑞subscript𝜒subscript𝒳𝑞𝜒subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2superscriptsubscript𝑏11superscriptsubscript𝑏21E({\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}})=\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}a_{1},a_{2}\in{\mathcal{A}}\\ \gcd(a_{1}a_{2},q)=1\end{subarray}}\ \sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}b_{1},b_{2}\in{\mathcal{A}}\\ \gcd(b_{1}b_{2},q)=1\end{subarray}}\frac{1}{\varphi(q)}\sum_{\chi\in{\mathcal{X}}_{q}}\chi\left(a_{1}a_{2}b_{1}^{-1}b_{2}^{-1}\right),

where, as usual, φ​(q)𝜑𝑞\varphi(q) denotes the Euler function. Changing the order summation, and separating the contribution

1φ​(q)​∑a1,a2∈𝒜gcd⁡(a1​a2,q)=1∑b1,b2∈ℬgcd⁡(b1​b2,q)=11≤A2​B2φ​(q)1𝜑𝑞subscriptsubscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2𝒜subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2𝑞1subscriptsubscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2ℬsubscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2𝑞11superscript𝐴2superscript𝐵2𝜑𝑞\frac{1}{\varphi(q)}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}a_{1},a_{2}\in{\mathcal{A}}\\ \gcd(a_{1}a_{2},q)=1\end{subarray}}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}b_{1},b_{2}\in{\mathcal{B}}\\ \gcd(b_{1}b_{2},q)=1\end{subarray}}1\leq\frac{A^{2}B^{2}}{\varphi(q)}

from the principal character, we obtain

(2.1) E​(𝒜,ℬ)≤A2​B2φ​(q)+R,𝐸𝒜ℬsuperscript𝐴2superscript𝐵2𝜑𝑞𝑅E({\mathcal{A}},{\mathcal{B}})\leq\frac{A^{2}B^{2}}{\varphi(q)}+R,

|R|≤A​B​qo​(1).𝑅𝐴𝐵superscript𝑞𝑜1|R|\leq ABq^{o(1)}.

φ​(q)≫qlog⁡log⁡(q+2)much-greater-than𝜑𝑞𝑞𝑞2\varphi(q)\gg\frac{q}{\log\log(q+2)}

see [7, Theorem 328], we conclude the proof.     ⊓square-intersection\sqcap⊔square-union\sqcup

2.3. Number of solutions to some congruences with reciprocals

An important tool in our argument is an upper bound on the number of solutions Jr​(q;K)subscript𝐽𝑟𝑞𝐾J_{r}(q;K) to the congruence

1x1+…+1xr≡1xr+1+…+1x2​rmodq,1≤x1,…,x2​r≤K,formulae-sequence1subscript𝑥1…1subscript𝑥𝑟modulo1subscript𝑥𝑟1…1subscript𝑥2𝑟𝑞formulae-sequence1subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥2𝑟𝐾\frac{1}{x_{1}}+\ldots+\frac{1}{x_{r}}\equiv\frac{1}{x_{r+1}}+\ldots+\frac{1}{x_{2r}}\bmod q,\quad 1\leq x_{1},\ldots,x_{2r}\leq K,

where r=1,2,…𝑟12…r=1,2,\ldots.

We start with the trivial bound 1≤K≤q1𝐾𝑞1\leq K\leq q we have

(2.2) J1​(q;K)≪K.much-less-thansubscript𝐽1𝑞𝐾𝐾J_{1}(q;K)\ll K.

For r≥2𝑟2r\geq 2 and arbitrary q𝑞q and K𝐾K, good upper bounds on Jr​(q;K)subscript𝐽𝑟𝑞𝐾J_{r}(q;K) are known only for r=2𝑟2r=2 and are due to Heath-Brown [8, Page 368] (see the bound on the sums of quantities m​(s)2𝑚superscript𝑠2m(s)^{2} in the notation of [8]). More precisely, we have:

Lemma 2.3.

For 1≤K≤q1𝐾𝑞1\leq K\leq q we have

J2​(q;K)≤(K7/2​q−1/2+K2)​qo​(1).subscript𝐽2𝑞𝐾superscript𝐾72superscript𝑞12superscript𝐾2superscript𝑞𝑜1J_{2}(q;K)\leq\left(K^{7/2}q^{-1/2}+K^{2}\right)q^{o(1)}.

It is also shown by Fouvry and Shparlinski [6, Lemma 2.3] that the bound of Lemma 2.3 can be improved on average over q𝑞q in a dyadic interval [Q,2​Q]𝑄2𝑄[Q,2Q]. The same argument also works for Jr​(q;K)subscript𝐽𝑟𝑞𝐾J_{r}(q;K) without any changes.

Indeed, let Jr​(K)subscript𝐽𝑟𝐾J_{r}(K) be the number of solutions to the equation

1x1+…+1xr=1xr+1+…+1x2​r,1≤x1,…,x2​r≤K,formulae-sequence1subscript𝑥1…1subscript𝑥𝑟1subscript𝑥𝑟1…1subscript𝑥2𝑟formulae-sequence1subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥2𝑟𝐾\frac{1}{x_{1}}+\ldots+\frac{1}{x_{r}}=\frac{1}{x_{r+1}}+\ldots+\frac{1}{x_{2r}},\qquad 1\leq x_{1},\ldots,x_{2r}\leq K,

where r=1,2,…𝑟12…r=1,2,\ldots. We recall that by the result of Karatsuba [10] (presented in the proof of [10, Theorem 1]), see also [3, Lemma 4], we have:

Lemma 2.4.

For any fixed positive integer r𝑟r, we have

Jr​(K)≤Kr+o​(1).subscript𝐽𝑟𝐾superscript𝐾𝑟𝑜1J_{r}(K)\leq K^{r+o(1)}.

Now repeating the argument of the proof of [6, Lemma 2.3] and using Lemma 2.4 in the appropriate place, we obtain:

Lemma 2.5.

3.2. Proof of Theorem 1.2

We proceed as in the proof of Theorem 1.1, in particular, we set J=⌈log⁡(N/2)⌉𝐽𝑁2J=\left\lceil\log(N/2)\right\rceil.
